ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Did Olympic Games improve air quality in Beijing? Based on the synthetic control method

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: During preparations for the Olympic Games, Beijing issued a series of environmental policies to increase environmental governance. Using Synthetic Control Method, which appeared in a comparative case study recently, we estimated the impact of the Beijing 2008 Olympic Games on Beijing’s air quality in this paper. The results show that Beijing’s air quality significantly improved after 2008; average annual air pollution days reduced by 25 days, and the result is significant on the level of 3.2 %. But after 2010, these effects disappeared gradually. Furthermore, considering winter is the most polluted season of Beijing, this paper further examined the impact of these environmental policies on the air quality in winter. We find that after the Olympics, the improvement of air quality in Beijing mainly occurred in other seasons, winter air quality did not significantly improve.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
In recent 30 years, China’s economy has experienced rapid growth. But, to a great extent, this growth is at the cost of consuming resources and energy. This development mode caused the deterioration of ecological environment and the aggravation of environmental pollution. Air pollution, among all kinds of pollutions, is definitely in the spot light. It severely impairs health by causing respiratory diseases, and more importantly, nobody can escape from it. According to a report of the World Bank (1997), owing to air pollution, China has 178000 premature deaths and 75.99 million case of asthma every year. The respiratory disease has become the fourth cause of death of people from city and countryside.
China health statistics yearbook, 2012.

As the problem of environmental pollution has become more and more serious, china started to put controlling environmental pollution in an important position. In 1998, the State Environmental Protection Administration was established. And then quite a few of laws and regulations for environmental protection were issued. In order to control the increasingly serious problem of acid rain and restrict the emission of sulfur dioxide, the central government defined the areas which had produced or would produce acid rain as acid rain control areas, and designated the sulfur dioxide polluted areas as sulfur dioxide control district. According to these basic conditions, 175 cities have been listed. In order to contain control environmental pollution, the local government has issued a series of specific measures, including eliminating boilers which use much energy and heavily damage the environment, controlling the emission of sulfur dioxide from heat-engine plant, building many facilities which do not produce sulfur dioxide, and so on. In recent years, new economic punishments and incentive mechanisms have also been established, e.g., fining people who don’t obey the law, subsidizing to consumers for using energy efficient and environment-friendly products, granting emission rights, prohibiting to use lead gasoline, and so on.

However, did these environmental policies significantly improve the environmental quality? And if yes, how should we evaluate the effect? The questions above motivate this study. This paper uses Synthetic Control Method, which appeared recently in a comparative case study to estimate the influence of environmental policy to environmental quality in the case of Beijing Olympic Games.

Since the international Olympic committee announced on July 13, 2001, that the 29th Olympic Games would be held in Beijing, air pollution has always been the focus of debate in countries all over the world. In order to show its determination of pollution control to the world, the Beijing organizing committee for the Olympic Games chose “Green Olympics” as the slogan of the 2008 Beijing Olympics. During preparations for the Olympic Games, Beijing city government issued a series of policies to improve the air quality, including the closure of factories; Replacing furnaces and installing desulfurization equipments, like desulfurizing and deducting for coal-fired boiler which were more than 20 tons; applying clean energy for coal-fired boiler which was less than 20 tons; issuing new emission standard and strict traffic control, like executive standard of Europe-III automobile emission standard from 2008, updating out old taxis and buses, keeping vehicles off the road on alternate days based on license plate numbers to control the number of vehicles and so on.

The purpose of this paper is to evaluate whether or not the Olympic Games in Beijing improved the air quality in a quantitative way. As only Beijing has been affected by a series of policies aiming to improve air quality, we thus can treat these policies as a natural experiment conducted on Beijing. We define Beijing as the treatment group, and find a control group to analyze the influence of the environmental regulations on the air quality in Beijing. Considering that the environmental regulations brought out by Beijing Olympic Games did not affect other cities, we can choose the latter as the control group, and use the difference in difference method to estimate the effect of the environmental regulations. However, to adapt the method above, the choice of control group is limited by a series of conditions: members of the control group should share a common time trend with the treatment group, but not be affected by the policies imposed on the latter. As a result, when these assumed conditions cannot be satisfied, we could not find the corresponding reference object to form a counterfactual group, and thus cannot accurately estimate the effect of the policy. The Synthetic Control Method fills in this gap. It provides a general method to solve the problem of choosing control group in the comparative case studies.

There are a vast number of works on the effect of environmental regulations on air quality. Chen et al. (2011) provides a comprehensive literature review on this topic. He further compares the change of Beijing air quality before, during and after the Olympic Games. Using official reports of the air pollution index, Chen finds that the air quality in Beijing had been significantly improved during and after the Olympic Games, but he also argues that the improvement would disappear by about 60 % a year after the Olympic Games. Henderson (1996) thinks local air quality regulation is very important. It not only affects local air quality, but also determines the choice of the location of factories. However, whether or not the regulations can achieve its initial goal of design is closely related to the degree of local regulatory efforts. Kathuria (2002) studies the influence of prohibiting the use of leaded gasoline and the old commercial vehicles in New Delhi; he finds that the air quality in New Delhi did not improve with traffic control. The main reason is that the control only applied to new cars, not to old cars before the regulation. Davis (2008) assesses the effect of traffic control in Mexico. In 1989, the Mexico City determined that every car was forbidden to use in weekends. Similar to the logic of Kathuria (2002), this policy did not improve the air quality. On the contrary, the air pollution was more serious in weekends. Kumar and Foster (2009) find that while the air quality in New Delhi was improved, the air quality in surrounding areas became worse than before as many high polluting industries moved there because the surrounding areas did not have air quality regulations.

Chen et al. (2011) put Beijing and the five Olympic co-host cities as treatment group by the method of difference in difference, and choose the other cities as control group. As in the treatment group, the difference in air quality between Beijing and the other five cities was remarkable before the intervention of the policy, also was the difference in the strength of the environmental policies. So if we put these six cities together to evaluate the effect of the environmental policy, some problems may arise.
The difference of air quality between Beijing and the other five cities is very large. In the preparation for the Olympic Games, Beijing has issued a series of environmental policies, while the other five cities’ environmental policy strength is relatively small because of their air quality is better than Beijing. So if we put these cities together to estimate the effect of environmental policy, we might overestimate the impact of environmental policy. In contrast to Chen et al. (2011), this paper only put Beijing as the treatment group and estimated Beijing’s quality improvement by holding the Olympic Games. Besides, the Synthetic Control Method can effectively solve the problem of the choice of the control group. The conclusions of the previous literatures (Henderson 1996; Kathuria 2002; Davis 2008; Kumar and Foster 2009) are mostly the correlation between the environmental policy and the air quality. But as a rigorous scientific research, we must distinguish between causation and correlation. Based on the natural experiment of the Beijing Olympic Games, this paper compares the difference in the air quality between Beijing and the control group before and after the Beijing Olympic Games using the Synthetic Control Method as the basis of a causal relationship between the environmental regulation and air quality. Therefore, this paper put the research of environmental regulation and air quality one step forward.

This article also involves a wider range of research on environmental pollution. There are a large number of domestic and foreign literatures that study the effects of environmental pollution on health. Almond et al. (2009) have studied the air pollution caused by China’s winter heating. Because of the historical accident, the cities in the north of Qinling-Huaihe have collectivized heating, while in the south of Qinling-Huaihe, people cannot enjoy the winter heating. Meanwhile, if the winter is extremely cold, more coal should be burned for heating in the north; while in the south, there is no collectivized heating no matter how cold or warm the winter gets. In general, they find that the TSP (total suspended particulates) in northern cities is higher than that in the southern ones; given a decline of 1 degree Celsius in air temperature, the induced TSP content increase in northern cities tends to be greater than that in southern cities by 180 mg per cubic meters. Moreover, the researchers find that prenatal TSP raised by every 100 μg/m3, the baby’s weight dropped by an average of 14 grams, by comparing the weight of babies born in north and south, they further argue that people who are seriously affected by the pollution are infants in the risk of low birth weight. Currie and Walker (2011) have researched the damage to the health of people from automobile exhaust. By collecting data of newborn babies in the United States, the scholars divided them into two groups, in one group the distance between the babies and the toll station is within 2 km, and in the other group the distance is 2–10 km. They found, in the first group, the preterm birth rate of newborn infants had declined by 10.8 %, and the ratio of underweight was reduced by 11.8 %, after the electronic toll collection system started. While in the second group, the new babies did not get affected by this policy. These results verified the causal relationship between the automobile exhaust pollution and the health of the newborn babies.

This paper estimates the effect of Olympic Games on the air quality in Beijing using Synthetic Control Method. It is found that the air quality was remarkably improved in Beijing between 2008 and 2010, and the days of average annual air pollution reduced to the number of 25. The robustness test reveals that our results are significant at 3.2 % level. But after 2010, the effects of environmental policy on Beijing air quality disappeared gradually. Especially in 2012, Beijing’s air quality returned to levels last seen before the Olympic Games. This illustrates the unsustainability of the policy effect. In order to guarantee the air quality in Beijing during the Olympic Games, many environmental policies, such as vehicle restrictions, limiting production of pollution industrial enterprise, were carried out. So once the Olympic Games end, the government relaxed regulation. Because of these reasons and some other climate factors, the Beijing’s air quality becomes worse.

Considering the air pollution is worse in winter than in other seasons in Beijing, we also investigate the air quality in winter Beijing. We find that the improvement of air quality mainly occurred in other seasons except winter after Olympic Games. The air quality in winter did not distinctly improve. This is a relatively pessimistic conclusion. As the number of days which are air polluted in winter accounts for about half of the pollution days all over a year, so the effect of improvement on air quality from Beijing Olympic Games is very small as a whole. The main reasons include the unsustainability of the effect of the environmental policies, winter heating and climatic factors, these factors led to the result that Beijing’s air quality in winter did not improve.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows: Sect. 2 makes a brief introduction of the policy background and the data we use. Section 3 introduces the method of estimation. Section 4 estimates the influence of environmental regulations on the air quality using the Synthetic Control Method. In Sect. 5, we consider all kinds of factors which may affect the conclusion and carry out a series of robustness test. In Sect. 6, we examine the impact of these environmental policies on the air quality in winter. Finally, Sect. 7 concludes.

Section1.Heading: Policy background, data and descriptive statistics
Section1.Para:
This paper uses balanced panel data from 47 key environmental protection cities in the country in 2001–2012 to analyze the influence of the hosting of Beijing Olympic Games on Beijing’s air quality. Considering Tianjin, Shanghai, Shenyang, Qingdao, and Qinhuangdao are the co-host cities of Beijing Olympic Games and Lhasa’s data are missing for some years, we remove these cities from analysis. The remaining 41 cities constitute the control group.
These 41 cities include the capital of 32 province except Shanghai Tianjin, Liaoning, Tibet, Hong Kong, Macao, Taiwan (That is Shijiazhuang, Changchun, Haerbing, Nanjing, Hangzhou, Hefei, Fuzhou, Guangzhou, Taiyuan, Zhengzhou, Wuhan, Changsha, Nanchang, Xi’an, Lanzhou, Yinchuan, Xining, Huhehaote, Wulumuqi, Guiyang, Nanning, Haikou, Kunming), plus Dalian, Suzhou, Nantong, Lianyungang, Ningbo, Wenzhou, Xiamen, Yantai, Shenzhen, Zhuhai, Shantou, Zhanjiang, Guilin and Beihai.

We use the number of polluting days each year in every city as an indicator of air quality. Data are from the data center of Ministry of Environmental Protection of the People’s Republic of China (MEP). From 2001, the state environmental protection administration monitors the air quality of the key environmental protection cities and reports air pollution indices every day. According to the classification of urban air pollution from MEP, this paper defines the air pollution index above 100 as a threshold for polluted air. When the air pollution index (API) is above 100, health will be affected when people take part in outdoor activities, especially when there is a moderate pollution or a heavy pollution. According to the synthetic control method, the weights of different components of the synthetic city are determined such that the air conditions of the synthetic Beijing are close enough to the real Beijing. Our control variables include the annual gross value of industrial output, investment in environmental governance, the number of industrial furnaces, coal use (including feed coal and bunker coal), and per capita green area. The data are from China City Statistical Yearbook, 2002–2011, and China Environment Yearbook, 2002–2011.

Since Beijing had already been affected by policy impact of improving air quality during its preparation for the Olympic Games, we expect Beijing’s air quality improvement happened prior to 2008. So it may cause biases if we take the year 2008 as a division of the policy impact point to estimate policy effects. To address this issue, we determine the starting point of the policy impacts as described below.

According to the Data Center of State Environmental Protection Administration, the three kinds of main air pollutants in Beijing are sulfur dioxide from the burning of coal, nitride oxides that come from vehicle exhaust emissions, and total suspended particulate matter from energy consumption. A weaker form of traffic control continued after the Games as each registered vehicle was required to be off the road 1 weekday per week.

Section1.Heading: Estimation method
Section1.Para: In order to estimate the influence of environmental regulations on the air quality in Beijing, this paper uses the Synthetic Control Method to form a reasonable comparison for the treatment group. There are different time trends in treatment group and control group before policy shocks, and they may remain after using difference in difference. As a result, it’s difficult to accurately estimate the policy effect. The synthetic control method (Abadie et al. 2010) is used to address this difficulty. The basic idea of it is as follows: we choose all the areas which are not subject to the policy shocks as the control group, and give a weight to each area. Each area’s weight is chosen according to the following rules: we try a great number of different weighted control groups to simulate the actual situation of the treatment group. When the simulation results are unbiased, we choose the current vector of weights to form a counterfactual group after policy shocks.

The details of Synthetic Control Method can be found in Abadie et al. (2010).

The Synthetic Control Method allows for effect estimation in settings where a single unit (a state, country, firm, etc.) is exposed to an event or intervention. It provides a data-driven procedure to construct synthetic control units based on a convex combination of comparison units that approximates the characteristics of the unit that is exposed to the intervention. A combination of comparison units often provides a better comparison for the unit exposed to the intervention than any comparison unit alone. Moreover, data-driven procedures reduce discretion in the choice of the comparison control units, forcing researchers to demonstrate the affinities between the affected and unaffected units using observed quantifiable characteristics. The model extends the traditional linear panel data (difference in differences) framework, allowing that the effects of unobserved variables on the outcome vary with time.

Unlike the difference in differences, synthetic comparison group is a weighted average of comparison individual, so it made clear that each control group’s contribution in constructing the synthetic comparison group.

In recent years, Synthetic Control Method has been widely used in the comparative case studies. In political science, Abadie and Gardeazabla (2003) study the influence of Spanish Basque terrorist attacks on its economy by constructing a counterfactual group of Basque by the areas which were not under terrorist attacks, they find that, after the outbreak of terrorism in the late 1960’s, per capita GDP in the Basque Country declined about 10 % points relative to a synthetic control region without terrorism. Abadie et al. (2014) evaluate the impact of German reunification in 1990 for West Germany’s economic development using synthetic control method. They found that because of the German reunification the per capita GDP of West German fell by $1600 a year between 1990 and 2003. In 2003, the per capita GDP of synthetic West German is 12 % higher than the real West German. In regional economics, Wang and Nie (2010) study the influence of adjustment of administrative division on economic growth using the case that Chongqing was set up for municipalities directly under the central government in 1997, and they also used this method to construct a counterfactual group of Chongqing. In this paper, we try to use Synthetic Control Method in environmental economics, and evaluate the impact of environment policy on urban air quality. The contribution of this paper is to improve the accuracy of the estimation for environment policy.

Section1.Heading: The influence of the Olympic Games on Beijing’s air quality
Section1.Para:
We execute a Synth software package to analyze our model based on the Synthetic Control Method introduced in the preceding section.
Synth software package was provided by Abadie et al (2010), and this software package mainly used for estimating the policy effect in comparative case study. Table 3 presents the comparison of predictive variables between the actual Beijing and the synthesis of Beijing before 2007. From Table 3, we can see the number of industrial furnaces, coal use (including feed coal and bunker coal), and Greenland per capita are the same between Beijing and the synthesis of Beijing except the annual gross value of industrial output and the investment in environmental governance. The annual gross value of industrial output and the investment in environmental governance in synthesis of Beijing are less than those of real Beijing. The main reason for this big gap between both is that Beijing is the capital of China, and its economic development level is far higher than other cities in China. As a result, the investment in environmental governance is higher than other cities too. Besides, the number of pollution days each year in 2002, 2004, 2006 of the synthesis of Beijing all fit well with that of the real Beijing. But there is a remarkable gap between the average value of pollution level in synthetic Beijing and Beijing. Figure 1 presents the pollution days per year on average in Beijing and the control group from 2001 to 2010. From the figure, we can see the pollution days per year on average have different time trends between Beijing and the control group. The pollution days in Beijing decline faster every year. So the method of difference in difference cannot give a difference to the time trend. If we use the difference in difference to estimate the influence of the Olympic Games on Beijing’s air quality, we may get a biased result.

Section2.Heading: Permutation test
Section2.Para: Is the improvement of Beijing’s air quality after 2007 just an accident or because of a nationwide trend? Is this conclusion also established for other cities in China? For this purpose, we conduct a series of robustness tests. We use the Permutation test brought by Abadie et al. (2010) gauge if our results to are statistically significant. The main idea of the permutation test is to randomly select a city in the control group, and assume that this city has been affected by the Olympic Games. Then we use the Synthetic Control Method to conduct a synthetic city for it, and get the probability that it has the same result with Beijing. We test all the 41 cities in the control group by placebo test, and calculate the difference in the number of pollution days between every real city and its synthetic city. As a statistical test, if we find the difference for Beijing is significantly different from the other cities, it means the impact of Olympic Games on Beijing’s air quality is significant.

We use the predictive variable before 2007 to form the air pollution situation of every city, which is in turn utilized to estimate the air pollution situation after 2007. If the syntheses of some cities are different from the real situations, it means the synthesis cities do not fit well with the real values. So if we compare the prediction error of other cities and the prediction error of Beijing, we may get unreliable statistical inference. Before 2007, the prediction error between the synthetic Beijing and Beijing is 4 days. In the control group, we remove cities whose average prediction errors are twice than that of Beijing. There are 9 cities in the control group. Among them, Shijiazhuang has the biggest prediction error. Its average prediction error is 18 days. Figure 4 shows the prediction error distributions of the 31 cities in the control group. We can see that the prediction error of Beijing is not very different from those of other cities, but the difference becomes bigger after 2007. The prediction error in Beijing is negative. It says that the number of pollution days influenced by the Olympic Games in Beijing declines year by year. And the prediction error in Beijing is smaller than that of other cities, which implies that the improvement of other cities’ air quality is not as significant as Beijing’s. In contrast, the prediction errors in some other cities are positive and exhibit an increasing trend, i.e., the air quality was deteriorating. Therefore, if we randomly select a city in the control group to get the same effect with Beijing, the probability is 1/32 (3.2 %), and we thus argue that the influence of the Olympic Games in Beijing’s air quality is significant at the 3.2 % level.

Section2.Heading: Further verification
Section2.Para:
In order to test whether it’s appropriate to make 2007 as the right point in time of policy shocks, and whether the estimated results are influenced by the time point selection, we separately choose the year of 2006 and 2008 to be the time point to compare the changes in Beijing’s air quality before and after the policy, and compare with the results above. Figure 5 shows the number of pollution days every year of Beijing and the synthetic Beijing in 2006 and 2008 which is the policy impact point in time, and we find the conclusion is not too much different from the previous result. From the figure, we can see the number of pollution days in Beijing is much bigger than the number in synthetic Beijing in 2006 and 2007 when the timing of the policy impact is the year 2006. But the number in Beijing is smaller than the number in synthetic Beijing after 2008, which means the air quality in Beijing did not improve before 2007. It also means it is inappropriate to take the year 2006 as the timing of the policy impact. Chen et al. (2011) also came to the conclusion that Beijing’s air quality did not improved significantly before the start of the Olympic Games. So this paper chooses 2007 as the policy impact of the point in time is appropriate.

Air pollutants often spread over a region during the change of meteorological processes such as wind and rainfall in the region, as well as in the neighborhood regions. In order to maintain the air quality of Beijing during the Olympics, the governments of six areas including Beijing, Tianjin, Hebei, Shanxi, Inner Mongolia and Shandong jointly set up Air Quality Coordination Group for Beijing 2008 Olympic Games.
China Environment Yearbook, 2007. This group is responsible for the air quality of Beijing 2008 Olympic Games. So these areas may be affected by the Olympic Games, and the air quality in these areas may be improved. If we put these places into the Control Group, we might underestimate the influence of the Olympic Games on Beijing’s air quality. To test this hypothesis, we remove Shijiazhuang, Taiyuan, Hohhot and Jinan from the Control Group, leaving the rest 36 cities to re-estimate the influence of Olympic Games on air quality in Beijing. We use the same method to evaluate the difference of the number of pollution days between Beijing and the synthetic Beijing. The result shows the difference of the number is 28 in 2010, which is not very different from previous results. In this case, Lanzhou (0.421), Wuhan (0.575) and Ningbo (0.004) share the largest three weights.

In order to reduce air pollutant emissions, the high pollution and high-energy consumption enterprises were relocated. We wonder whether Beijing’s air quality improvement is at the cost of the other cities’ air quality. Kumar and Foster (2009) found that although the air quality in New Delhi had been improved, the air quality in surrounding areas became worse as the pollution-intensive industries moved in. Taking this possibility into account, we should make sure that cities in the Control Group were not subject to effects of the Olympic Games, i.e., these cities are not the immigration destinations into which the pollution-intensive firms in Beijing are moving. Otherwise, the improvement of Beijing’s air quality is not the result of environmental regulations, but the result of the migration of the pollution-intensive industries. In order to check whether this possibility exists, we refer to the relevant information and find that all the cities in the Control Group are not the ingoing places for the pollution-intensive industries. For example, Capital iron and steel company and Beijing Coking Plant moved to Tangshan city, Beijing Chemical Plant, The Second Beijing Chemical Plant moved to the Fangshan district of Beijing, Beijing dyestuff plant moved to the Hengshui city and Langfang city. Of course, if the high pollution enterprise of Beijing did not move to the cities in the control group, then the effects of environmental policy were underestimated, which did not affect the main conclusions of this paper.

Section1.Heading: The persistence of policy effects
Section1.Para:
From the pollution index, the air quality in northern cities is much worse in winter than in other seasons. In Beijing, the number of pollution days every year in winter accounts for roughly half of the number of pollution days throughout the year. In 2004, the percentage was the lowest for 43 %. In 2007, the percentage is the highest for 56 %. Did the air quality improvement mainly occur in winter after the Olympic Games? In order to test the seasonal difference of air quality, we compare the change of Beijing’s air quality in winter before and after the Olympic Games. We rely on the heating time in winter to determine when the winter comes and leaves. At present, Beijing’s winter heating period is from November 15th to March 15th of the following year. So we only consider the change of Beijing’s air quality on November to March the next year. We use the number of pollution days in winter in the cities from the Control Group to synthesize the pollution days in winter in Beijing and calculate the difference in the number of pollution days in winter in Beijing and in the synthetic Beijing. As illustrated in Fig. 5, the gaps are 6, 8, and 6 days for 2008, 2009 and 2010, respectively. Comparing these numbers to the year-long gaps of 12, 27 and 36 days for the same period, we argue that Beijing’s air quality has not improved significantly in winter. The decline in the number of pollution days in winter accounts for only a small fraction of all the year round. It can be concluded that Beijing’s air quality improvement mainly happened in other seasons after 2007 (Fig. 6).
Fig. 6
Pollution days gap between Beijing and synthetic Beijing in winter

Why did not Beijing’s air quality in winter improve significantly after 2007? The main reasons may be: (1) the effect of the environmental policy adopted for the Beijing Olympic Games was short-lived, and the improvement of the environment disappeared in a short time. During the Olympic Games, Beijing strictly controlled the number of the local and nonlocal cars on the road, which largely reduced the automobile exhaust emissions. After the Olympic Games, Beijing relaxed the restrictions on car. Chen et al. (2011) also found that the influence of the Olympic Games on the improvement of Beijing’s air quality was short-lived, and this improvement disappeared by about 60 % a year after the end of the Olympic Games. (2) Heating in winter. As the main energy of heating is coal in Northern China, it creates massive emissions of sulfur dioxide. Almond et al. (2009) found the air quality in northern cities is worse than in southern cities because of heating by comparing the north and south cities along the Huaihe river and Qinling. During the preparation for the Beijing Olympic Games, no policies aiming to improve heating efficiency were carried out. (3) Climate factors. Beijing climate is dry, windy, and is often affected by foreign and local sand and dust. The Particle Pollution index (PM10) of Beijing often is extremely high in winters. And air pollution caused by climate factors did not change after the Olympic Games.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: This paper studies the effects of a series of environmental policies issued by the government of Beijing to deal with the air quality during the Beijing Olympic Games. We treat this as an experiment that provides us a good chance to study the effects of environmental policies. The current research adopts the synthetic control method in comparative case studies to avoid the problem of difference between the treatment group and the control group; this increases the reliability of our results. The synthetic control method is a nonparametric method. It uses the data to construct an appropriately chose synthetic reference object. As a result, this method extends and improves the traditional difference in difference method.

It if found that the air quality has been improved significantly. The number of average pollution days every year reduces to 25 between 2008 and 2010, and the results are significant at the 3.2 % level. But after 2010, the policy effect was gradually weakened, especially in 2012, Beijing’s air quality returned to levels last seen before the Olympic Games. Therefore, the Olympic Games have no long-term effects on air quality of Beijing.

The reason why Olympics could not bring long-term improvements to the air quality in Beijing was that many policy measures were short-term provisions. For example, the environmental policies like high polluting enterprises reduce capacity and driving restriction were canceled after the Olympic Games, thus environmental policy lack of persistence. In China, evaluations of local officials are mainly based on GDP; local government officials only care about the economic development in their tenure of office and ignore the long-term impact of economic development, such as environmental problems. Local officials might pollute for promotion because energy conservation efforts are poorly valued by the Chinese Cadre Evaluation System. Furthermore, as the subordinate departments of local government, the environmental protection department’s behavior will inevitably influenced by the local government intervention. When there is excessive focus on economic development and the environmental protection by the local government is ignored, it is often difficult for the local environmental protection department to supervise and restrict the pollution behavior of enterprise. In addition, the short-term characteristics of Chinese officials tend to encourage short-term speculation, because environmental policy takes a long time to produce results. For officials in pursuit of political promotion, their enthusiasm for strictly carrying out the environmental policy will be weakened if it cannot produce an immediate effect (Eaton and Kostka 2014).

Therefore, to achieve lasting effort for environmental policies, the policy itself must keep continuity. If the central government wants effective implementation of environmental policies in local governments, the central government needs to adjust the evaluation methods for local officials. Add the environmental costs of economic development into the evaluation system of local officials, at the same time, extend the term of office in the same position for local officials.

In the future, it’s necessary to strengthen environmental regulations in Beijing. And special attention should be paid to the environmental management in winters. In addition, if we want to get the lasting effects, the policy must be persisting, which means that each area should follow its environmental governance. This article only analyses the effects of environmental regulation on the air quality. What about the welfare effect of the environmental policy? It remains to be answer whether the environmental policy significantly changed the behavior of the enterprise, and whether it significantly improved the health of the people? These question will be the focus of our follow-up studies.
